block.p: DaimlerChrysler A.G. said today that it would spend $500 million to consolidate all its electronic-commerce activities in a single venture, DCX Net Holdings.

The new company will oversee all of the DaimlerChrysler business-to-business, business-to-customer, business-to-employee and telematics activities. Telematics involves the use of computer and telecommunications technology to create intelligent transportation management systems.
DaimlerChrysler A.G. said today that it would spend $500 million to consolidate all its electronic-commerce activities in a single venture, DCX Net Holdings.

The new company will oversee all of the DaimlerChrysler business-to-business, business-to-customer, business-to-employee and telematics activities. Telematics involves the use of computer and telecommunications technology to create intelligent transportation management systems.

DCX Net will be the centerpiece of a companywide effort at efficiency. It will encompass existing programs like Covisint, the Internet marketplace started recently by DaimlerChrysler, Ford, General Motors and Renault/ Nissan.

DaimlerChrysler, based in Auburn Hills, Mich. and Stuttgart, Germany, makes Dodge, Eagle, Jeep, Plymouth, and Mercedes cars. Its Daimler-Benz unit also makes commercial vehicles and aerospace products.
DaimlerChrysler shares rose $1.01, or 2.3 percent, to $44.91 on the New York Stock Exchange.
